S2095-4956(15)00053-4 10.1016/j.jechem.2015.08.006 Fig. 1 A schematic of a high-temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell using solid oxide electrolyte membrane. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Images of as-received Sn particles: TEM image of (a) nano-sized Sn, SEM images of (b) micro-, and (c) macro-sized Sn. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Picture and (b) schematic diagram of an in-house built high temperature liquid Sn-air energy storage cell. (c) Cross-sectional SEM image of an electrolyte supported cells. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Characterization of the thermal and electrochemical oxidation behaviors of different Sn particles. (a) Normalized TGA curves at 5 °C/min under atmospheric pressure conditions using air as an oxidant. (b) Variations of open circuit voltage as function of temperature. Anode: 100 mL/min Ar. Cathode: (i) air 50 mL/min until 750 °C and (ii) O2 50 mL/min once heated at 750 °C. (c) The inset shows the SEM image of nano SnO whisker at the anode after monitoring the OCV using micro-sized Sn. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Cross-sectional SEM images with EDX element color maps of Sn (red), Ni (green), and O (blue) after monitoring the OCV using (a) and (a-1) nano-sized Sn and (b) and (b-1) micro-sized Sn (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Schematic representation showing the Sn initial particle size effect on a high temperature liquid Sn-air energy storage cell. (a) Using nano-size Sn and (b) using micro- and macro-sized Sn fuels. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Comparison of the electrochemical performances of a high temperature liquid Sn-air energy storage cell. (a) Polarization curves of the cell using nano-, micro-, and macro-sized Sn fuel with O2 and air (50 mL/min). (b) Variations of the discharge curves of the cell at a constant current density of 10 mA/cm2 and 50 mA/cm2 using nano-sized Sn fuel. Fig 7 Table 1 Summary of theoretical properties, electrochemical reaction for possible high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell. Theoretical open circuit voltage for the electrochemical oxidation calculated based on thermodynamic data [39,50–52]. Theoretical capacity calculated based on active fuel metals only, including O2 but not air. Table 1 m.p. (°C) Electrochemical oxidation reaction OCV (V) at 750 °C Energy density (kWh/L) at 750 °C 49In 157 2In + 3O2 − → In2O3 + 6e− 0.98 4.84 50Sn 232 Sn + 2O2− → SnO2 + 4e− 0.96 6.25 51Sb 630 2Sb + 3O2− → Sb2O3 + 6e− 0.75 3.31 82Pb 327 Pb + O2− → PbO + 2e− 0.65 2.20 83Bi 272 2Bi + 3O2− → Bi2O3 + 6e− 0.48 1.64 Table 2 Comparison of the measured electrochemical data for OCV and high frequency resistance (HFR) at 750 °C with air and O2. Table 2 Temperature (°C) Fuel Nano-sized Sn Micro-sized Sn Macro-sized Sn OCV (V) HFR (Ω·cm2) OCV (V) HFR (Ω·cm2) OCV (V) HFR (Ω·cm2) 750 with air 0.82 1.8 0.60 N/A 0.68 2.1 750 with O2 0.95 1.5 0.86 2 0.87 1.5 High-temperature liquid Sn-air energy storage cell HyungKuk Ju a Jaeyoung Lee a b * a ERTL Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis, Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE), Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, Gwangju 500-712, South Korea ERTL Center for Electrochemistry and Catalysis Research Institute for Solar and Sustainable Energies (RISE), Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology Gwangju 500-712 South Korea b Electrochemical Reaction and Technology Laboratory (ERTL), School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology, Gwangju 500-712, South Korea Electrochemical Reaction and Technology Laboratory (ERTL) School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Gwangju Institute of Science and Technology Gwangju 500-712 South Korea * Corresponding author. Fax: +82 62 715 2434. Α new type of a high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell based on solid oxide electrolyte has been successfully demonstrated at 750 °C by feeding metal Sn. In order to understanding the initial size effect of metal as a liquid fuel, we report here the impact of the thermal and electrochemical oxidation behavior of nano Sn (∼100 nm), comparing with micro-sized (∼5 µm) and macro-sized (∼350 µm) Sn. The thermogravimetric analysis and the monitoring OCV test indicate that the distinct property of nano-sized Sn results in a favorable thermal oxidation behavior near the melting point and a promising power performance due to enhanced fuel transport to the anode. However, the accumulated Sn oxide at the reaction interface during a discharge test towards the limitation of further electrochemical oxidation. Graphical abstract A high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell in conjunction with a solid oxide electrolyte-based system has been successfully demonstrated by using nano-sized Sn fuels. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Nano tin Metal-air battery Solid oxide electrolyte Thermal oxidation Discharge behavior 1 Introduction Metal-air batteries have been intensively explored as an alternative future energy storage and conversion systems owing to their intrinsically high energy and power densities, the relatively mature research on air electrode, and cost effective composition of non-noble fuel electrode, as well as in response to the high energy demand for portable devices and electric vehicles even stationary power plants [1–5]. Of late, research into the metal-air techniques has been focused on Zn-air (∼1000 Wh/kg), Li-air (∼13,000 Wh/kg), and Ge-air (∼1500 Wh/kg) batteries because of its very high specific energy and energy density with open cell air cathode structure [3–6]. With these devices, however, the electrochemical energy could be stored in the stationary part as a form of sacrificial metal anode. This distinct architecture would make a limitation approach for large-scale commercialization unless the anode can provide good electrochemical reversibility and high cyclic durability. As a feasible alternative to continuous operation, recently, a high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell (LMAESC) in conjunction with a solid oxide electrolyte has been investigated applying post-transition metals such as In [7], Sn [7–17], Sb [18–25], Pb [7], and Bi [12] as a sacrificial electrode, so-called liquid metal anode (LMA). Since these liquid metals has relatively low melting point, it can improve the anode polarization by incorporating liquid wetting materials to spread on the solid ceramic surfaces such as yttria‐stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrolyte and Ni-YSZ anode. Another approach is to operate in a direct carbon fuel cell in order to enhance wetting of solid carbon fuels at anode/electrolyte interface as an electrochemical mediator [26–31]. This concept first employed, in 1989 by Costa et al. [32], using a fused Fe gasifier reactor in order to utilize solid coal. Gopalan et al. [33,34] reported liquid metal Ag and Sn, as a consumable feed dispersed in a Ni-YSZ anode and the system suggested in two different modes: (i) in a solid oxide electrolyzer mode to generate hydrogen gas using coal and steam and (ii) in a solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) mode to produce electricity using hydrogen. CellTech Power [8–11] has energetically developed a liquid tin anode solid oxide fuel cell (LTA-SOFC) over more than a decade to operate various carbonaceous fuels. The role of LTA is a non-structural fluid cell component so it is highly tolerant of impurities. Gorte and his group [7,12,13,18–20,25] also proposed that various liquid metal (In, Pb, Sb, Sn, Bi, and Ag) fuel cells and flow batteries based on the SOFC. Specially, they focused on molten Sb/Sb2O3 anode and the direct utilization of sugar char and bio-oil was examined that the stable operation with a peak current density of around 250 mW/cm2 at a constant voltage of 0.5 V was demonstrated for up to 250 h [20]. Similarly, Shi et al. [14,21–24] has reported using liquid metallic Sb and Sn in terms of the effect of the interface morphology of the electrolyte, the influence of temperature in the metal/metal oxide interaction, and the reaction kinetics. Currently, the LMA SOFC was studied on the transport behavior of oxygen in the bulk surface Sn and the thermochemical partitioning of coal contaminates in the LMA system by National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) [35,36]. Otaegui et al. [37] tested a high temperature liquid metal-air battery at a current density of 10 mA/cm2 at 800 °C. The discharge capacity was achieved around 4–13 mAh/cm2 with more than 1000 charge/discharge cycles by applying the electrochemical treatment of the cell. Among liquid metal candidates facing the development of the LMAESC, Sn is very attractive material due to its relatively low melting point (232 °C), high volumetric energy density (6.25 kW/h), and low cost (US$ 22.27 kg−1) [38], as summarized in Table 1. The liquid Sn metal can be galvanically oxidized to SnO2 owing to the negative Gibbs free energy change of −365 kcal/mol at 750 °C [39]. (1) Sn + 2 O 2 − → Sn O 2 + 4 e − E 0 = 0.96 V Fig. 1 represents a schematic of the operation principle of a LMAESC cell via high-temperature solid oxide electrolytic route. Despite these attractive benefits, the use of liquid metal fuels is still challenging because of the formation of insulating oxide layers at reaction site, high surface tension and sluggish oxygen-ion migration through the solid electrode interface [7,14,35–37]. Moreover, most of these studies applied the bulk sized metal sources and there is no distinct report on the effect of different size of metal particles on the energy storage and conversion performance. Here we have studied new insight regarding the energy storage performance of the LMAESC based on solid oxide electrolytes and the effect of the initial metal fuel size on the thermal- and electro-oxidation behaviors using a thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and an in-house built high temperature fuel cell test station. 2 Experimental Three different sizes of Sn particles were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich: macro-sized (> 250 µm, average size 350 µm, purity > 99%), micro-sized (< 45 µm, average size 5 µm, purity > 99.8%), and nano-sized (< 150 nm, average size 100 nm, purity > 99%) Sn, as shown in Fig. 2 . Before an energy storage performance test, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA; Shimadzu TGA-50A, Japan) was carried out to find out the relationship between thermal oxidation behaviors and electro-catalytic oxidation characteristics of Sn particles. The electrolyte-supported button-shaped SOFC single cell (NEXTCELL, Fullcellmaterials, USA) consisted of a porous Ni-GDC/Ni-YSZ anode (50 µm), a dense ZrO2-based electrolyte (150 µm) and a porous LSM/LSM-GDC cathode (50 µm), as detailed in Fig. 3 . The diameter of the cell was 28 mm and the active area corresponding to the cathode layer was 1 cm2. Pt wires (99.99%, 0.5 mm, Alfa Aesar) and Pt mesh (99.9%, 52 mesh woven, Alfa Aesar) were applied as a current collector. In order to prevent air leakage, two gaskets (Thermiculite 866, USA) in the form of rings were mounted with a sandwich arrangment of the cell and then ceramic adhesive (Aremco 668, USA) was pasted around the alumina tubes. Sn fuels were prepared with 1 g of Sn powders and dissolved in 0.2 mL of ethylene glycol (Junsei Chemical Co., Ltd., Japan). The Sn-air energy storage cell was performed by placing the as-prepared Sn fuel slurry directly into the anode. Prior to heating up the system, inert Ar gas (purity 99.999%, 50 mL/min) was flowed through the anode chamber to remove residual gas for over 1 h. The oxygen sensing measurement (NeoFox, Ocean Optics, USA) was conducted the reactor outlet. In the experiment, less than ca. 3.5% of the oxygen was detected. High purity O2 gas (purity 99.99%, 50 mL/min) was then fed into the cathode. The alumina ceramic reactor placed inside a furnace (NARA Cell-Tech, South Korea) and the operating workstation (Scitech Korea, South Korea) was used for the evaluation of cell performance. In order to determine the real-time response of the variation in the ohmic contact resistance, the high frequency resistance (HFR) of the cell was monitored at a fixed frequency of 1 kHz using an AC-impedance meter (3560 AC mΩ HiTester, Hioki, Japan) [26,40]. The surface morphology and elemental analysis were carried out via a field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM; S-4700, Hitachi, Japan) and a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM; JEOL, JEM-2100, Japan) and the elemental qualitative analysis of the cell was investigated using an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX; EMAX 7200-H, Horiba, England) coupled with the FE-SEM. 3 Results and discussion In order to advance the understanding of the size-dependent thermal oxidation behaviors of Sn particles, TGA curve was performed under atmospheric pressure conditions using Air as an oxidant, as shown in Fig. 4( a). The thermal oxidation was started at room temperature and performed under isothermal and heated to 800 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. With nano-sized Sn, a very sharp weight gain of 12 wt% was observed at around 200 °C and the curve exhibits a slight increase at 700 °C with a further weight gain of 11 wt% and then it may reach a quasi-plateau at this temperature. This much early oxidation observation is in good agreement with previous studies [41,42]. In addition, it indicates that the first distinct curve is also due to the influence of a notable melting of Sn nanoparticles before normal Sn melting point of 232 °C. In particular, the remarkably fast oxidation phenomenon may attributed to the nano size effects such as the increase surface-to-volume ratio, reactivity and the depression of melting temperature [43,44]. Unlike for the nano-sized Sn, the thermal oxidation starts at over 550 °C using micro- and macro-sized Sn particles. In addition, the total weight gain of these three Sn indicates different values. The order of weight gain was micro-sized Sn (26 wt%) > nano-sized Sn (23 wt%) > micro-sized Sn (13 wt%). The oxidation of three types of Sn was started at ∼200 °C with nano-sized Sn, at ∼580 °C with micro-sized Sn, and after 600 °C with macro-sized Sn. From these results, although micro-sized Sn has a slightly higher total oxygen capacity than nano-sized Sn, the onset oxidation temperature of nano Sn exhibits a significantly lower temperature than that of micro- and macro-sized Sn. Thus, we suggested that the diffusion or solubility of oxygen and thermal oxidation reactivity of the Sn can be also affected by the initial size of Sn particles. To provide an electrochemical oxidation evaluation for a high temperature LMAESC performance on the porous Ni-GDC/Ni-YSZ anode, the open-circuit voltage (OCV) was measured until 750 °C under inert atmosphere (Ar gas). In Fig. 4(b), an onset potential of all three different Sn was occurred at 350 °C. The nano-sized Sn shows the highest stable OCV of 0.95 V after purging O2 in the cathode, while the OCV of the cell feeding micro- and macro-sized Sn fuels was about 0.86 V and 0.87 V, respectively. The measured OCV for the nano-sized Sn is close to the expected theoretical Nernst potential for Sn oxidation (See Eq. (1)). It could be resulted from the favorable oxidation activity and the facilitated accessibility of early melted nano Sn on the porous anode surface into the triple phase boundary (TPB) i.e., the interface between fuel (reactant)-Ni (electronic conductor and catalyst)–YSZ or GDC (ionic conductor). Table 2 was summarized the measured OCV and HFR for ohmic contact resistance in AC mode. The expected ohmic contact resistance value of 150 µm YSZ is about 0.57 Ω. cm2 at 750 °C, based on the reported ionic conductivity of YSZ of 0.0188 S/cm at 700 °C and 0.0428 S/cm at 800 °C [45]. However, the observed HFR value exhibits a two- to three-fold higher increase in the value of ohmic resistance. As mentioned introduction, this observation indicates that the electrochemical oxidation of Sn fuels undergoes a forming oxide layer at the reaction interface, thereby leading to the increases in ohmic resistance due to its poor ionic/electronic conductivity of Sn oxide, as well as the presence of insulating SnO2 could deactivate the anode by blocking reaction active sites leading to an increase the polarization resistance [12,14,35,37]. Interestingly, the monitoring OCV profiles with micro- and macro-sized Sn display a steep OCV drop between 500 °C and 600 °C. This observed potential drop indicated that the oxidation of Sn could exist in two different oxidation states for SnO and SnO2. We assumed that the decreased OCV with increasing temperature could be ascribed to a Schottky-like rectifying barrier with the co-existent semiconductor interface of SnO (p-type) and SnO2 (n-type) at the Ni-based anode, leading to reduce electronic conductivity [46,47]. Again, it might be reoccurred p- to n-type conductivity transition with the oxidation states for Sn due to further increasing temperature. The formation of narrow whisker at the anode was observed as shown in Fig. 4(c). This result indicates that the growth of Sn oxide whiskers contains lower oxidation states of Sn (SnO), attributed to the low oxygen solubility [42,48,49]. Fig. 5 presents SEM and EDX element mapping analysis for after monitoring anode. The analysis data confirmed that the presence of nano-sized Sn can be capable of transporting more favorable into the reaction active sites of anode due to the well-spread at the anode surface with improving the wetting behavior of early melted Sn. In contrast to using nano-sized Sn, the SEM image of the cell with micro-sized Sn shows an agglomerate layer onto the anode and the identified Sn in EDX map (red spots) shows only near to the anode outer surface due to dewetting of Sn particles. As expected, the possible reactive surface could be improved because of the faster liquefied nano Sn fuels and the effective contact area with TPB at the anode, corresponding to 101–103 times higher surface area of nano Sn than micro- and macro-sized Sn fuels. Based on considering these experimental observations, we suggested that a schematic illustration of the plausible mechanistic origin of electrochemical oxidation of liquid Sn at the solid porous anode is described in Fig. 6 . After the nano-sized Sn fuel melted, the porous anode could be widely covered with the liquefied Sn and the electro-oxidation of Sn fuels can occur at the anode due to enlarge reaction surface areas at the anode (Fig. 6(a)). In case of Sn micro- and macro-sized Sn fuels, the electrochemical oxidation of Sn may be limited by the sluggish migration of oxygen ions and the poor electron conductivity due to the poor contact between dewetted Sn and solid anode and to the formed passivation SnO2 layers (Fig. 6(b)). In order to clarify the influence of the Sn fuel size on the power performance of LMAESC, we carry out the polarization curves at 750 °C, as shown in Fig. 7( a). With applying micro- and macro-sized Sn fuels, a large activation polarization and IR-drop in the cells were observed over the all current density regions. On the other hands, the cell with nano-sized Sn fuels with air and O2 shows a reasonable OCV of 0.92 V and 0.95 V, respectively, closed to the Nernst potential and the maximum power densities of 32 mA/cm2 and 60 mA/cm2 were achieved, respectively. These results indicated that the power performance was enhanced four- to six-times using nano fuels, but there is an intrinsic difficult problem to solve associated with the IR-drop of the cell due to the passivation of SnO2. In Fig. 7(b), we performed a discharge test using nano-sized Sn fuel with air and O2 at a discharge current of 10 mA/cm2 and 50 mA/cm2 at 750 °C in order to provide a reasonable comprehensive for the durable LMAESC performance. The discharge profile displays a stable power output up to 18 mAh/cm2 using 1 g of Sn fuel with O2 in the cathode and then a rapid degradation of the cell was observed. From this discharge performance, however, the overall fuel efficiency was calculated only ∼5%. Most of Sn fuels were hardly utilized in this system. Regarding the degradation question from this interesting point of view, we suggested that this limited energy capacity could be caused by the accumulated insulating SnO2 layers at the anode leading to the sluggish electrochemical reaction and to blocking its further oxidation of Sn fuel. 4 Conclusions We have researched the effect of size dependent thermal and electrochemical oxidation behavior of different size of Sn on the high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell. Our results indicate a new insight into the liquid metal electrochemical reaction that the nano-sized Sn has the favor thermal oxidation reactivity at close to its melting temperature and the improving wetting behavior at the anode with enhancing fuel transportation. The stable OCV of 0.95 V with a peak power densities of 60 mA/cm2 is demonstrated at 750 °C for operation on nano-sized Sn fuel. However, some unsolved problems still remain at to the stable performance how could remove the accumulated insulating SnO2 layers at the anode reaction interface. We anticipated that it can be possible to solve the undesirable converting problem to the SnO2 using other reactants in combined with the direct carbon fuel cell system. coredata.dc:description: Α new type of a high temperature liquid metal-air energy storage cell based on solid oxide electrolyte has been successfully demonstrated at 750 °C by feeding metal Sn. In order to understanding the initial size effect of metal as a liquid fuel, we report here the impact of the thermal and electrochemical oxidation behavior of nano Sn (∼100 nm), comparing with micro-sized (∼5 µm) and macro-sized (∼350 µm) Sn. The thermogravimetric analysis and the monitoring OCV test indicate that the distinct property of nano-sized Sn results in a favorable thermal oxidation behavior near the melting point and a promising power performance due to enhanced fuel transport to the anode. However, the accumulated Sn oxide at the reaction interface during a discharge test towards the limitation of further electrochemical oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: High-temperature liquid Sn-air energy storage cell
